Title: Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star
Poem: Twinkle, twinkle little star, how I wonder what you are. Up above the world so high, like a diamond in the sky. Twinkle, twinkle little star, how I wonder what you are.
PoemToPixel: The main theme of "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star" revolves around curiosity and wonder, particularly in relation to the night sky and its celestial bodies. The mood is whimsical and reflective, evoking a sense of innocence and fascination as the speaker contemplates the nature of stars. Notable literary devices in the poem include simile, as seen in the comparison of the star to a "diamond in the sky," and repetition, which emphasizes the speaker's sense of awe and enhances the musical quality of the verse. The simple, childlike tone invites readers to share in the wonder of the universe.

Title: Wheels on the bus
Poem:
The wheels on the bus go round and round.
 Round and round, round and round.
 The wheels on the bus go round and round.
 All day long.The wipers on the bus go swish, swish, swish, swish...
 The horn on the bus goes beep, beep, beep...
 The children on the bus go wriggle, wriggle, wriggle...
 The grown-ups on the bus go chatter, chatter, chatter...
 The babies on the bus go wah,wah,wah...
PoemToPixel:
The main theme of the poem revolves around the lively and repetitive activities on a bus, capturing the various sounds and movements associated with a bus ride. The mood is playful and cheerful, evoking a sense of joy and nostalgia often associated with childhood experiences. 
 

 Notable literary devices used in the poem include repetition, which enhances the musical quality and reinforces the rhythm, and onomatopoeia, as seen in words like "swish," "beep," and "wah," which bring the sounds of the bus to life. This playful use of sound words creates an engaging atmosphere that resonates with children, making the poem both entertaining and memorable.

Title: Ba Ba Black Sheep
Poem:
Baa, baa, black sheep.
 Have you any wool ?
 Yes Sir, Yes Sir,
 three bags full.
 One for the Master,
 one for the Dame.
 And one for the little boy,
  who lives down the lane.
PoemToPixel:
The poem "Baa, Baa, Black Sheep" presents a simple and playful theme centered around a conversation with a black sheep about wool. The mood is light-hearted and cheerful, invoking a sense of childhood innocence and curiosity. 
 

 Notable literary devices include repetition, as seen in the repeated phrases "Yes Sir, Yes Sir," which creates a rhythmic quality suitable for a nursery rhyme. The use of rhyme enhances the musicality of the poem, making it memorable and engaging for children. Additionally, the personification of the sheep allows for an imaginative interaction, appealing to a young audience's sense of storytelling. Overall, the poem blends whimsical imagery with a straightforward narrative, making it a classic in children's literature.

Title: Jack and Jill
Poem:
Jack and Jill went up the hill
 to fetch a pail of water.
 Jack fell down and broke his crown
 and Jill came tumbling after.
PoemToPixel: The main theme of the nursery rhyme "Jack and Jill" explores the concept of adventure and the unpredictable nature of life, encapsulated in a simple story of children fetching water. The mood is lighthearted yet tinged with a sense of mischief and misfortune, as the playful tone contrasts with the accidents that occur. Notable literary devices used include rhyme, which creates a musical quality, and alliteration with the repetition of consonant sounds, enhancing the rhythm of the poem. The use of personification in the characters’ actions adds to the charm and relatability of the narrative.

Title: Humpty Dumpty
Poem:
Humpty Dumpty sat on a wall.
 Humpty Dumpty had a great fall.
 All the King’s horses
 and all the King’s men,
 couldn’t put Humpty together again.
PoemToPixel:
The main theme of the poem revolves around the fragility of life and the impossibility of restoring something once it is broken. The mood is melancholic and poignant, evoking a sense of loss and inevitability. 
 

 Notable literary devices include rhyme, demonstrated through the structured couplets (e.g., "wall" and "fall"), which create a rhythmic flow. The use of alliteration in "King’s horses" and "King’s men" adds musicality to the poem. Additionally, the imagery of Humpty Dumpty as a fragile figure emphasizes vulnerability and the harsh reality of irreversibility.
